See How Alex Honnold Climbed a Dizzying 1,667-Foot-Tall Skyscraper Without Ropes
He became famous after scaling El Capitan without protective equipment in 2017. Now the 40-year-old athlete has completed the first free solo of Taipei 101 in Taiwan
American rock climber Alex Honnold climbed to the top of the Taipei 101 skyscraper without using any ropes, making him the first person to free solo the iconic building in Taiwan‚Äôs capital city.
Honnold completed his gravity-defying stunt on January 25, one day later than initially planned, because of rain. From top to bottom, the unassisted climb of the 1,667-foot-tall tower took about 90 minutes.
For the feat, which was broadcast live on Netflix with a ten-second delay, Honnold wore a red T-shirt, black pants and yellow climbing shoes. He also had a small white bag of chalk attached to his waist, which he periodically dipped his hands into to get a better grip on the metal structures, ledges and beams that make up the building‚Äôs exterior.
The 40-year-old athlete ascended a corner of the building using only his own strength to support himself. He stopped periodically to rest as he methodically inched his way upward, but he told NBC News‚Äô Yuliya Talmazan, Molly Hunter and Lauren Selsky afterward that he never felt too tired to continue.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs kind of like a happy tired, you know, like if you‚Äôre running a race or something. By the end of the race, you‚Äôre like, ‚ÄòOK, I‚Äôm getting tired, but I know I‚Äôm going to cross the finish line, and I feel great,‚Äô‚Äù he said.
As he focused all of his attention and energy on completing each move, he ‚Äúkind of lost track of space and time to some extent,‚Äù he added.
Onlookers watched from the street as well as from inside the 101-story building made from steel and glass. When he finally reached the top of the tower‚Äôs spire and began waving his arms over his head, many erupted into cheers.
The presence of spectators was a bit of a new experience for Honnold, who typically climbs in secluded wilderness areas.
‚ÄúWhen I was leaving the ground, you‚Äôre like, ‚ÄòOh, it‚Äôs kind of intense, there‚Äôs so many people watching,‚Äô‚Äù he told Katie Tam of the Associated Press after completing the historic Taipei 101 climb. ‚ÄúBut then, honestly, they‚Äôre all wishing me well. I mean, basically it just makes the whole experience feel almost more festive; all these nice people are out supporting me and having a good time.‚Äù
While Alain Robert, a French climber who calls himself ‚ÄúSpider-Man,‚Äù climbed the tower in 2004, he used safety equipment for his ascent, making Honnold the first to achieve the endeavor entirely without ropes. When Robert made his climb more than two decades ago, Taipei 101 was the tallest building in the world‚Äîa title now held by the 2,717-foot-tall Burj Khalifa in Dubai.
‚ÄúIt feels infinite,‚Äù Honnold told NBC News of the building. ‚ÄúWhen you look up, all you can see is building as far as you go, and so it just keeps going forever.‚Äù
According to the New Yorker‚Äôs Charles Bethea, Taipei 101 is the tallest building anyone has ever climbed without ropes. The next tallest is probably one of the 1,483-foot-tall Petronas Twin Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, which Robert free-soloed in 2009, according to Climbing magazine‚Äôs Maya Silver.
Honnold has summited plenty of the world‚Äôs most challenging natural structures. He famously completed a ropeless ascent of El Capitan, a vertical granite formation in Yosemite National Park, in June 2017. However, for more than a decade, he‚Äôd dreamt of adding Taipei 101 to his r√©sum√©, according to CNN‚Äôs Jessie Yeung, Wayne Chang and John Mees. The opportunity finally materialized after Netflix got involved.
Did you know? Free Solo wins big
The documentary about Honnold‚Äôs ascent of El Cap, called Free Solo, won the 2019 Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature.
Honnold hasn‚Äôt shared the exact amount he was paid for the stunt. But according to the New York Times‚Äô Adam Skolnick, his compensation was in the ‚Äúmid-six figures.‚Äù The climb took place with the full support and permission of Taipei 101 and the local government.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a freestanding, almost 1,700-foot tower that‚Äôs very hard to get access to,‚Äù Honnold told the New Yorker ahead of the climb. ‚ÄúThen suddenly somebody gives you permission. It‚Äôs like, obviously you say, ‚ÄòYes.‚Äô And then they‚Äôre like, ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre going to pay you to do it.‚Äô And you‚Äôre like, That‚Äôs so cool. Not only do I get to do it, they‚Äôre going to pay me‚Äîthat‚Äôs sick.‚Äù
Honnold said he hoped the ascent would motivate others to go after their dreams.
‚ÄúMaybe they‚Äôll watch something like this, and it‚Äôll be a reminder that their time is finite, and they should use it in the best way they can,‚Äù he told Netflix‚Äôs Elle Duncan after finishing the ascent, as reported by the Hollywood Reporter‚Äôs Patrick Brzeski. ‚ÄúIf anything, I hope that‚Äôs what people take from it‚Äîthat if you work really hard, you can do hard things, and maybe they should try.‚Äù

This Hammer Created From an Elephant Bone 480,000 Years Ago May Be the Oldest Known Tool of Its Kind Ever Found in Europe
Discovered in southern England in the mid-1990s, the artifact may have been made by Neanderthals or Homo heidelbergensis, according to a new study
In the mid-1990s, archaeologists unearthed a piece of elephant bone from a site in southern England. It didn‚Äôt look like much at the time, so they set it aside in the collection of the Natural History Museum in London.
Now, decades later, scientists have determined the long-overlooked artifact was more than just a bone fragment. Writing in a paper published January 21 in the journal Science Advances, they argue that the specimen is a 480,000-year-old hammer that was created deliberately‚Äîpotentially by Neanderthals or the species Homo heidelbergensis. If the researchers‚Äô conclusions are correct, that would make the tool the oldest of its kind in Europe.
Whichever species created it, the discovery suggests they were ‚Äúsophisticated in their use of tools,‚Äù says study co-author Silvia Bello, a researcher at the Natural History Museum, in a statement.
‚ÄúCollecting and shaping an elephant bone fragment and then using it on multiple occasions to shape and sharpen stone tools shows an advanced level of complex thinking and abstract thought,‚Äù she adds.
The fragment was discovered at an archaeological site in Boxgrove, a small village located about 60 miles south of London. Recently, scientists decided to revisit the four-inch-long artifact, using an electron microscope to take a closer look.
Their investigation revealed the bone was studded with pits, marks and scores‚Äîsome that appear to have been made by slicing, others by scraping‚Äîwhich indicates it was well-used. In some of the marks, they found tiny, embedded fragments of flint, suggesting the bone may have been used to sharpen stone tools.
Researchers think it was a ‚Äúsoft hammer,‚Äù a type of instrument made from antlers and mammal bones. They were commonly used for knapping, ‚Äúa process where stones, bones or even antlers are struck against the edges of dulled stones to detach flakes and restore their sharpness,‚Äù as BBC Wildlife magazine‚Äôs Will Newton writes.
At Boxgrove, archaeologists suspect soft hammers were used for numerous purposes, including the production of handaxes. The 480,000-year-old tool was probably a rare ‚Äúretoucher‚Äù used for lighter tasks that required more precision, such as refining and sharpening the cutting edges of stone tools used at butchery sites.
‚ÄúThe use of soft hammers and retouchers allowed for greater control in the knapping process compared to hard hammers, enabling early humans to produce more finely shaped and efficient tools,‚Äù the researchers write in the paper.
Did you know? Neanderthals feasted on straight-tusked elephants
- Some Neanderthals figured out how to hunt and butcher straight-tusked elephants, which provided enough meat to feed 25 individuals for three months.
- Researchers came to this conclusion after finding repetitive cut marks on 125,000-year-old animal bones discovered in central Germany.
Roughly 480,000 years ago, during the Lower Paleolithic, Europe was brimming with straight-tusked elephants and steppe mammoths. But the behemoth creatures were largely absent from southern England, which means their bones‚Äîand the tools created from them‚Äîwere probably considered highly valuable.
‚ÄúNo other elephant remains were found [at the site], so it is likely that this bone was brought in from somewhere else,‚Äù Bello tells IFL Science‚Äôs Benjamin Taub.
So far, researchers have not been able to identify the species or part of the body the bone came from. It‚Äôs also unclear how the bone was obtained, but some evidence suggests it was shaped and used while it was relatively fresh. Either way, the findings indicate our human ancestors were ‚Äúresourceful gatherers of available materials and savvy about how best to use them,‚Äù Bello says in the statement.
A handful of elephant bone tools have been found elsewhere in Europe, but the oldest date to roughly 450,000 years ago. Most were found farther south, in places where elephants and mammoths were much more abundant.
Much older elephant bone tools have been found in Africa, including a trove of 1.5 million-year-old specimens recently unearthed in Tanzania. The hominins inhabiting the region must have been ‚Äúvery comfortable working with bone,‚Äù James Clark, an archaeologist at the University of Cambridge, told the New York Times‚Äô Carl Zimmer in 2025.

Sonic Booms and Earthquake Sensors Can Help Researchers Track Space Junk as It Plummets to Earth
Falling debris can travel at about 30 times the speed of sound, creating sonic booms that shake the ground
Unfortunately, hail and sleet are far from the only falling objects that may come crashing down on you‚Äîyou may need to watch out for the growing problem of plummeting space junk. As the number of spacecraft launches grows, so do the chances of debris from these devices dropping back to Earth.
Now, scientists have devised a clever new way to predict where the pieces may land.
When space junk barrels toward the planet‚Äôs surface, an object travels faster than the speed of sound, creating sonic booms in the atmosphere that slam into Earth. The subsequent shaking can be detected by earthquake sensors called seismometers, and the data can help researchers calculate the falling debris‚Äôs fragmentation, speed and trajectory in near real time, according to a paper published January 22 in the journal Science.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got these sensors already available, and we can use them for alternative means,‚Äù says John Crassidis, an aerospace engineer at the University at Buffalo who was not involved in the work, to Perri Thaler at Science. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really impressed with the steps they‚Äôve taken.‚Äù
The scientists developed the new technique by charting the trajectory of China‚Äôs defunct Shenzhou-15 spacecraft. While the crew capsule successfully delivered people to the Tiangong space station in 2022, it wasn‚Äôt designed to safely return to Earth. In April 2024, the module‚Äîabout 7 feet wide and 3,3000 pounds‚Äîuncontrollably re-entered the planet‚Äôs atmosphere over Southern California, creating a fiery light show.
Did you know? China‚Äôs Tiangong space station
China is not a partner of the International Space Station. So, in April 2021, the country launched the first module‚Äîwhich provides human life support and living quarters‚Äîof its own low-Earth orbit space station. The first cargo and crewed missions to it launched in the following months.
The plummeting debris posed risks to people not only because of its size, but also because such space junk can be toxic, flammable or radioactive.
As Shenzhou-15 fell, 125 seismometers throughout Southern California and Nevada recorded the ground shaking because of the spacecraft‚Äôs sonic booms. The researchers mapped out the ground-based devices‚Äô readings to calculate how the object broke into pieces and its path, and found that the module traveled northeast over Santa Barbara and Las Vegas at about ten times the speed of the world‚Äôs fastest jet, per a statement.
Moreover, the new method might be more accurate than current tracking techniques. The researchers estimate that Shenzhou-15 was traveling about 25 miles south of the U.S. Space Command‚Äôs prediction, which was based on the object‚Äôs orbit. But a rough re-entry can mess up those calculations, leading to weeks-long searches for dangerous fallen space debris‚Äîwhich might turn up empty, reports the New York Times‚Äô Robin George Andrews.
No debris has been recovered from Shenzhou-15, study co-author Benjamin Fernando, a planetary seismologist at Johns Hopkins University, tells Jacopo Prisco at CNN. ‚ÄúSo, all we can say is that we see something that is different to the Space Force prediction,‚Äù he adds.
‚ÄúIf somebody can go out and find pieces ‚Ä¶ that would be the real test,‚Äù says Samantha Lawler, an astronomer at the University of Regina in Canada who was not involved in the research, to the Times. Nevertheless, she says the work is ‚Äúincredibly useful.‚Äù
But a bigger question might be whether policymakers will invest in new methods to track falling space junk.
‚ÄúFor 60 years, we‚Äôve been letting things re-enter uncontrolled, knowing that, for the larger ones, some fraction will reach the surface,‚Äù says Jonathan McDowell, an astrophysicist at the Center for Astrophysics | Harvard & Smithsonian who also wasn‚Äôt involved in the study, to Scientific American‚Äôs Lee Billings. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve just been hoping that it doesn‚Äôt hit anyone on the head or cause other harm. But eventually, we‚Äôre going to run out of luck.‚Äù
Editor's note, January 26, 2026: An earlier version of this story misspelled Jacopo Prisco's name.

Tyrannosaurus Rex Was Probably a Late Bloomer‚Äîand May Have Taken Around 40 Years to Grow Up
The behemoth dinosaurs grew more slowly and had longer lifespans than previously thought, a new study suggests
Over the years, Tyrannosaurus rex has solidified its reputation as one of the most formidable predators to ever roam the Earth. But according to new research, these ferocious beasts probably weren‚Äôt full-grown until around 40 years old, meaning they spent much of their lives as smaller, less intimidating versions of the giants we imagine.
With a new paper published January 14 in the journal PeerJ, scientists provide an updated timeline for the extinct species‚Äô growth and development. Their investigation suggests that T. rex‚Äîa name that means ‚Äúking of the tyrant lizards‚Äù‚Äîprobably matured more slowly than previously thought.
‚ÄúIt took the prince a lot longer to grow into the king,‚Äù says Steve Brusatte, a paleontologist at the University of Edinburgh in Scotland who was not involved with the research, to Scientific American‚Äôs Cody Cottier.
Previous research, conducted in the early 2000s with a few fossils, suggested that the legendary dinosaurs reached their full size‚Äîup to around 20,000 pounds and 40 feet long‚Äîbetween 20 and 25 years old, and could live up to about age 30. Since then, however, additional T. rex bones have surfaced, which means scientists now have access to a larger sample size.
Fun fact: Heavyweight champion
Scotty the T. rex, whose bones are on display at the Royal Saskatchewan Museum in Canada, is the biggest known individual of its species. Researchers estimate that the dinosaur died around age 30 and would have weighed around 19,555 pounds and been around 42 feet long.
For the study, scientists investigated the tissue microstructures of the thigh and shin bones from 17 individuals of various ages. More specifically, they looked at the growth rings that formed annually in the T. rex bones‚Äîsimilar to the rings of a tree.
‚ÄúLeg bones tend to be one of the fastest growing bones in an animal, because they have to compensate for the weight as the animal is getting bigger,‚Äù says study co-author Holly Woodward, a paleohistologist at Oklahoma State University, to Science‚Äôs Jake Buehler. ‚ÄúSo, it‚Äôs going to tell us the most about how the animal was growing from year to year.‚Äù
They cut ultra-thin slices from the bones, then counted all the growth rings they could see‚Äîincluding groups of narrow rings bunched together that were overlooked in previous studies. They found even more rings when they looked at the samples using a special polarized-light technique.
Then, they combined the data to produce a new, detailed growth trajectory for the species. ‚ÄúThe composite growth curve provides a much more realistic view of how Tyrannosaurus grew and how much they varied in size,‚Äù study co-author Nathan Myhrvold, a mathematician and founder and CEO of Intellectual Ventures, tells IFLScience‚Äôs Stephen Luntz.
Growth rings appear to have stopped forming in T. rex leg bones after about 40 years, which suggests this is the age the reptiles reached maturity‚Äîif they managed to live that long. Most probably died before they ever reached their full adult size, according to the researchers.
Two of the specimens in the study grew more slowly than the others, which hints that they may have belonged to a different species‚Äîpossibly the controversial and diminutive Nanotyrannus lancensis described late last year. It‚Äôs also possible, however, that those individuals were simply sick or injured, or that some environmental hurdle stunted their growth.
Overall, the results offer fresh insights into what life may have been like for the legendary species, which lived during the Late Cretaceous period, some 68 million to 66 million years ago. For much of its life, the findings suggest, a T. rex roamed around as a small or medium-sized creature, and probably had to compete for food. Only once it reached its full, gargantuan proportions did it become an apex predator, the findings indicate.
The results may also prompt scientists to revisit the life cycles of more extinct species.
‚ÄúI expect that the estimates of growth curves of other dinosaurs will now have to be revisited,‚Äù says Thomas Carr, a paleontologist at Carthage College who was not involved with the research, to New Scientist‚Äôs James Woodford. ‚ÄúOverall, we‚Äôll see a shift in our understanding of dinosaur development across the board.‚Äù

Giant Kangaroos That Lived During the Ice Age May Have Hopped‚ÄîDespite Weighing Up to 550 Pounds
The extinct animals may have bounced from scary situations, such as coming face-to-face with hungry predators
For many people, thinking of Ice Age animals evokes images of woolly mammoths, saber-toothed tigers and giant sloths. But in prehistoric Australia, giant kangaroos also roamed the land. What‚Äôs more, these extinct behemoths may have hopped‚Äîdespite their massive weights, according to a study published January 22 in the journal Scientific Reports.
‚ÄúGiant kangaroos, their motion has been the subject of debate for a little bit now because they are so much larger than anything we have today,‚Äù Megan Jones, a mammal evolution researcher at the University of Manchester in England, tells ABC News‚Äô Julia Jacobo.
Previous research indicated that kangaroos weighing more than about 350 pounds would rupture their ankle tendons if they tried to hop. The largest of the Ice Age kangaroos, Procoptodon goliah, which went extinct around 40,000 years ago, may have weighed up to a whopping 550 pounds.
Did you know? Drivers of extinction
Some past research indicated that ancient humans, rather than climate change, may have hunted giant kangaroos into extinction. But a study published last fall suggests that Indigenous Australians simply hunted the creatures‚Äô fossils, not the animals themselves, and didn‚Äôt drive their disappearance.
But Jones and her colleagues noticed that past studies had primarily scaled up today‚Äôs kangaroos, which weigh up to about 200 pounds, to study the ancient ones‚Äîand may have overlooked important anatomical differences in the process.
So, the researchers examined hindlimb bones from a mixture of modern and extinct kangaroos and related animals, measuring a total of 139 modern specimens and 40 fossils representing 63 species. The team focused on two possible factors that could limit the ancient giants‚Äô ability to bounce: bone strength and tendon size.
Extinct kangaroos had shorter, thicker foot bones that could handle intense landing forces, the researchers found, as well as sufficiently wide bones in their heels for thick ankle tendons‚Äîway thicker than the ankle tendons of kangaroos today. In other words, the giant animals‚Äô anatomical features suggest that they could have hopped.
Still, ‚Äúwhether they did hop is a different question,‚Äù Jones tells New Scientist‚Äôs Chris Simms.
If they did, hopping likely wouldn‚Äôt have been their only means of travel. The thicker tendons probably lent themselves to sudden, brief hopping stints rather than long, bounding journeys, study co-author Katrina Jones, a comparative anatomist at the University of Bristol in England, says in a statement. The kangaroos probably hopped to traverse rough terrain or escape from predators, such as the marsupial lions of the Thylacoleo genus, the authors write in the paper.
Furthermore, the giant kangaroos may have moved in many different ways, the team found. Some seemed to have walked on four limbs, while others traveled upright on two legs, hinting that hopping may have been one of several forms of locomotion for these creatures.
More broadly, the new study might provide clues about why giant kangaroos disappeared, Gilbert Price, a vertebrate paleoecologist at the University of Queensland in Australia who was not involved in the study, tells the Guardian‚Äôs Nicola Davis.
‚ÄúIf you want to understand why these animals went extinct, you first have to understand what they were actually like,‚Äù he tells the outlet. ‚ÄúBringing the focus back to their biology and ecology isn‚Äôt just extra detail but is central to understanding what happened.‚Äù
